channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2025 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Fusion energy gets a boost from cold fusion chemistry
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02683-8

Chemists used an electrochemical method to enhance the rates of fusion in a desktop reactor — plus, how microbes give chocolate its taste.
item.dc:title: Fusion energy gets a boost from cold fusion chemistry
item.dc:creator: Shamini Bundell
Nick Petrić Howe

item.title: Proximity screening greatly enhances electronic quality of graphene
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09386-0

Screening by a graphite gate placed at 1 nm proximity to graphene produces transformative improvement in its electronic quality, reducing charge inhomogeneity by two orders of magnitude.
item.dc:title: Proximity screening greatly enhances electronic quality of graphene
item.dc:creator: Daniil Domaretskiy

item.title: Experimental determination of partial charges with electron diffraction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09405-0

An experimental method is used to assign partial charges based on crystal structure determination through electron diffraction, applicable to any crystalline compound.
item.dc:title: Experimental determination of partial charges with electron diffraction
item.dc:creator: Soheil Mahmoudi

item.title: Realization of a doped quantum antiferromagnet in a Rydberg tweezer array
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09377-1

A doped quantum antiferromagnet is obtained by using a Rydberg tweezer array comprising three levels encoding spins and holes to implement a tunable model that allows the study of previously inaccessible parameter regimes.
item.dc:title: Realization of a doped quantum antiferromagnet in a Rydberg tweezer array
item.dc:creator: Mu Qiao

item.title: Electrochemical loading enhances deuterium fusion rates in a metal target
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09042-7

A benchtop fusion reactor, called the Thunderbird Reactor, is described, showing that electrochemically loading a metal lattice with deuterium could enhance nuclear fusion rates when that metal is also bombarded by deuterium ions.
item.dc:title: Electrochemical loading enhances deuterium fusion rates in a metal target
item.dc:creator: Kuo-Yi Chen
Jannis Maiwald

item.title: Atomic dynamics of gas-dependent oxide reducibility
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09394-0

Environmental transmission electron microscopy reveals distinct atomistic pathways for the reduction of NiO to metallic nickel by CO and H2, with H2 more effective in transforming the entire bulk material.
item.dc:title: Atomic dynamics of gas-dependent oxide reducibility
item.dc:creator: Xiaobo Chen

item.title: Flat-panel laser displays through large-scale photonic integrated circuits
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09107-7

Photonic integrated circuits allow laser displays to be flattened into a compact form factor while improving efficiency and colour performance.
item.dc:title: Flat-panel laser displays through large-scale photonic integrated circuits
item.dc:creator: Zhujun Shi

item.title: Low-energy nuclear fusion boosted by electrochemistry
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02254-x

Electrochemistry can boost processes that trap atoms inside a metal. A reactor uses these trapped atoms, combined with an ion beam, as fuel for nuclear fusion.
item.dc:title: Low-energy nuclear fusion boosted by electrochemistry
item.dc:creator: Amy McKeown-Green
Jennifer A. Dionne
